Shane, 

Naturally I'm very interested in what a NEAT accelerator actually =

does.  My research group certainly does a lot of work with NEAT so we 
wou=
ld actually purchase something like that (assuming funds were 
available) i=
f the price was sufficiently competitive to be faster for 
the dollar compa=
red to something more simple like a regular CPU 
cluster.

So I think that =
is the main pricing question:  For $10,000, if you 
are efficient, you can =
buy maybe a 20-core cluster, which in effect 
is a 10x speedup from a regul=
ar 2-core CPU.  So a 20x speedup sounds 
economical if it is genuine.

Yet =
I am not clear how such gains would be made specifically with 
NEAT in mind=
?  One of the biggest expenses with running experiments 
with NEAT comes du=
ring evaluation in the task domain, which includes 
a lot of code (aside fr=
om the ANN activation method) that is not 
specific to NEAT.  In fact, in m=
any domains, it is task the domain 
simulation itself that takes the vast m=
ajority of CPU.  For example, 
a task trained in a robot simulator spends m=
ore time simulating the 
robot than doing anything NEAT-specific.  Of cours=
e, in some 
supervised applications (e.g. financial data) it is possible th=
at 
network activation takes up more CPU than the domain since the domain 
=
is in effect just a bunch of numerical comparisons.

So the questions is wh=
at exactly is being accelerated and how, so 
that a purchaser can be confid=
ent that they are going to get the 
offered speedup overall, and not just w=
hen NEAT-specific code is 
being called?

Anyway, sounds really interesting=
 and I'd enjoy hearing more about it.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"shanemcdonaldryan" 
<shanemcdonaldryan@...> wrote:
>
> My company is in th=
e process of developing a NEAT accelerator. This 
> would be a combination =
of hardware and software that accelerates 
the 
> process of evolving a pop=
ulation of networks for a particular NEAT 
> application.
> 
> We anticipat=
e a 20 fold reduction in training time compared to a 
> system running on a=
 single CPU Dual Core Pentium system. But this 
> would of course depend gr=
eatly upon the problem at hand.
> 
> The product will consist of an API wri=
tten in C that will interface 
> with a hardware system and accelerate the =
core functionality of the 
> NEAT algorithm.
> 
> A feature set and pricing=
 model has not been finalized.  Though to 
> make the product financially v=
iable a tentative price of $10K USD 
has 
> been estimated.
> 
> The reason=
 I am posting is to gauge interest. If you or your 
company 
> would be int=
erested in this product please send me an e-mail to: 
> ShaneR at RyanCapit=
al dot EU. Additionally if you have any 
questions 
> or concerns please e-=
mail me or post on this forum and will try and 
> answer them as quickly as=
 possible.
> 
> Thank you,
> 
> Shane
>
